verse.name: v1
verse.lines: Pale was the wounded knight That bore the rowan shield Loud and cruel were the raven's cries That feasted on the field, saying:

verse.name: v2
verse.lines: Beck water, cold and clear, Will never clean you wound. There's none but the Maid of the Winding Mere Can make thee hale and soond.

verse.name: v3
verse.lines: So course well, my brindled hounds, And fetch me the mountain hare Whose coat is a grey as the Wastwater Or as white as the lily fair, who said

verse.name: v4
verse.lines: Green moss and heather bands Will never staunch the flood. There's none but the Witch of the West-mer-lands Can save thy dear life's blood.

verse.name: v5
verse.lines: So turn, turn you stallion's head Till his red mane flies in the wind And the rider of the moon gaes by And the bright star falls behind.

verse.name: v6
verse.lines: And clear was the paley moon When his shadow passed him by; Below the hill was the brightest star When he heard the houlet cry, saying

verse.name: v7
verse.lines: Why do you ride this way, And wharfore cam' ye here? I seek the Witch of the West-mer-lands That dwells by the winding mere.

verse.name: v8
verse.lines: Then fly free your good grey hawk To gather the golden rod, And face your horse into the clouds Above yon gay green wood.

verse.name: v9
verse.lines: And it's weary by Ullswater And the misty brake fern way Till through the cleft o' the Kirkstane Pass The winding water lay.

verse.name: v10
verse.lines: He said, Lie down, my brindled hound, And rest my good grey hawk, And thee, my steed, may graze thy fill, For I must dismount and walk.

verse.name: v11
verse.lines: But come when you hear my horn And answer swift the call, For I fear e'er the sun shall rise this morn You will serve me best of all.

verse.name: v12
verse.lines: And down to the water's brim He's borne the rowan shield, And the golden rod he has cast in To see what the lake might yield.

verse.name: v13
verse.lines: And wet rose she from the lake, And fast and fleet gaed she, One half the form of a maiden fair With a jet black mare's body.

verse.name: v14
verse.lines: And loud, long, and shrill he blew And his steed was by his side; High overhead his grey hawk flew And swiftly he did ride, saying:

verse.name: v15
verse.lines: Course well, my brindled hounds, And fetch me the jet black mare. Stoop and strike, my good grey hawk, And bring me the maiden fair. She said:

verse.name: v16
verse.lines: Pray sheath thy silvery sword, Lay down thy rowan shield, For I see by the briny blood that flows You've been wounded in the field.

verse.name: v17
verse.lines: And she stood in a gown of the velvet blue, Bound 'round with a silver chain. She's kissed his pale lips aince and twice And three time 'round again.

verse.name: v18
verse.lines: And she's bound his wound with the golden rod; Full fast in her arms he lay, And he has risen hale and soond Wi' the sun high in the day. She said:

verse.name: v19
verse.lines: Ride with you brindled hounds at heel And your good grey hawk in hand. There's nane can harm a knight wha's lain With the Witch of the West-mer-land.
